metadata.title: Core@double-shell structured magnetic halloysite nanotube nano-hybrid as efficient recyclable adsorbent for methylene blue removal

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/cej
Core@double-shell structured magnetic halloysite nanotube nano-hybrid as efficient recyclable adsorbent for methylene blue removal
Xinyi Wana, Yingqing Zhana,b,c,⁎, Zhihang Longa, Guangyong Zenga, Yi Hea,b,c
a College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest Petroleum University, 8 Xindu Avenue, Chengdu, Sichuan 610500, China b Oil & Gas Field Applied Chemistry Key Laboratory of Sichuan Province, Southwest Petroleum University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610500, China c State Key Lab of Oil and Gas Reservoir Geology and Exploitation, Southwest Petroleum University, 8 Xindu Avenue, Chengdu, Sichuan 610500, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Halloysite nanotubes Fe3O4 Dopamine Core@double-shell Adsorption Methylene blue
A B S T R A C T
Design and fabrication of structurally optimized absorbents are important for wastewater treatment such as dyes and heavy metals removal. Herein, we reported the core@double-shell structured magnetic halloysite nanotube nano-hybrid absorbent with target micro-structure and high efficiency removal capacity of dyestuffs. Our core@ double-shell structured absorbent consisted of a halloysite nanotube as skeleton, an intermediate magnetic nanoparticles coating with more specific surface area and magnetic separation property, and poly(DA + KH550) derivate layer outside provided active adsorption sites. This well-defined core@double-shell configuration was quite distinct from conventional core-shell or hybrid structures. The integrated advantages of HNTs skeleton, Fe3O4 nanoparticles inner shell and poly(DA + KH550) outside shell contributed to the high adsorption capacity of methylene blue (up to 714.29 mg g−1) and excellent cycling stability. Furthermore, the novel core@doubleshell structured absorbent exhibited better removal efficiency for methylene blue in solution with high pH, and the adsorption process can be described by using the pseudo-second-order model. More importantly, the recycling process of adsorbents was more energetically and economically sustainable by using a permanent magnet. The characteristic high removal capacity, cycling stability and easy separation made core@double-shell structured absorbent promising for the efficient removal of dyestuffs from the wastewater.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid development of modern industry, water contamination has become a serious global problem. More importantly, wastewater containing synthetic dye which is derived from textile, leather, plastic, paper-making, cosmetics and other manufacturing is often directly discharged into the environment without any treatment [1]. Most dyestuffs can exist in natural environment for a long time and accumulate to higher concentration since they have complex aromatic structures which make them stable and hard-degraded [2], thus posing a great threaten to ecological environment and health of human beings. It has been found that ingestion of excessive dyes would cause direct damage to liver, digestive system and central nervous system of human beings [3]. Therefore, it is necessary to explore efficient methods to remove dyes from contaminated water prior to their discharge to protect the environment.
During the last decades, various techniques such as chemical oxidation [4], flocculation-coagulation [5], precipitation [6], photocatalytic degradation [7] and membrane filtration [8] have been developed to remove color dye-containing effluents. Although some
achievements have been made in the area of removal of dyes, these available methods also have their inherent limitations, such as high energy requirement, high operational cost and secondary pollutions etc [9]. Compared with these conventional methods, adsorption has received many attentions and become the major technique for removal of dyes from wastewater because it is low-cost, highly efficient and flexible in design and handing [10]. Up to now, many smart carbon based nanomaterials including carbon nanotubes [11] and graphene [12] were explored as adsorbents to remove dyes from wastewater. Although great success has been made, there are still some disadvantages such as high cost, toxic and inefficient regeneration. Therefore, searching for alternative adsorbents which are low cost, environment friendly and efficient regeneration is of high valuable.
In recent years, nano-sized halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) with hollow tubular structure have received increasing attentions due to their unique structural property and chemical stability [13]. Compared with carbon based nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes and graphene, halloysite nanotubes are chemically non-toxic, cheap, abundantly available and durable. Furthermore, the high specific surface area and relatively easy dispersion in water make them potentially be used as a

high performance adsorbent for removal of dyes [14]. On the other hand, traditional separation methods like centrifugation or filtration are time-consuming and uneconomical to separate adsorbents which are nano-sized. Therefore, to overcome recycling difficulties, magnetic nanoparticles were usually adopted to promote the magnetic separation after adsorption of pollutants from water by applying an external magnetic field, which has been proven to be an easy and economical method [15]. Therefore, preparation of a promising adsorbent which utilizes the advantages of both halloysite nanotubes and magnetic particles is highly considered. In last few years, many literatures have reported the preparation of magnetic HNTs composites adsorbents and their removal performance for contaminations from aqueous solution [16–18]. However, the adsorption capacity of these adsorbents is greatly restricted due to the scarcity of functional groups. Meanwhile, the loading of magnetic nanoparticles on the surface of HNTs is poor, which is due to the chemical inertia of HNTs surface. In fact, the adsorption capacity of these adsorbents for dyes is strongly controlled by the functionalization of HNTs and surface area available for adsorption. Therefore, ordered self-assembly, morphology control and surface functionalization of HNTs nanostructures are important for many applications. Unfortunately, it still remains a challenge to develop facile and reliable synthetic routes to prepare structure-controlled, highly efficient, and reusable magnetic HNTs adsorbents.
Recently, mussel-inspired surface modification for functional coatings was developed [19]. It was found that mussels showed the ability of strong adhesive property to attach onto various substrates by secreting Mytilus edulis foot protein [20]. Especially, the major ingredient of this adhesive protein is proven to be dopamine (DA). Although the adhesive mechanism remains rather complicated, a thin polymer layer would be formed on the surface of substrates. Generally, the DA is first oxidized to indole skeleton, followed by self-polymerizing into PDA via aryl–aryl linkages [21]. It has been reported that dopamine as binding agent between substrates and small molecules or nanoparticles has showed potential applications in many fields, such as biosensor [22], drug carrier [23] and analysis of protein [24], etc. Furthermore, the obtained polydopamine (PDA) with both catechol and amino functional groups can undergo reactions with the second functionalized monomers, which provides an alternative approach for further functionalization of many substrates. On the other hand, the silane coupling agents have been reported to modify the surface of nanostructured adsorbents for removal of pollutants in wastewater [25] since the amino groups of them can provide more adsorption sites. As a matter of fact, our previous works [26,27] have reported that a modified mussel-inspired method by introducing a silane coupling agent KH550 was used to modify some nanomaterials for preparing functionalized poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) membrane materials, which have potential application in oil/water separation or treatment of dyes from wastewater. In view of these facts mentioned above, the aim of this work is utilizing the adhesion of dopamine to immobilize Fe3O4 nanoparticles onto the surface of HNTs, thus realizing the structure and morphology control of core/shell magnetic HNTs nano-hybrids. Moreover, secondary functionalized monomer such as silane coupling agent KH550 was introduced into the PDA system, which would realize modified mussel-inspired co-modification of HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids by poly(DA + KH550). It is expected that such novel core@doubleshell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids would create a large number of adsorption sites for nano-hybrids, which make the target absorbent exhibit high adsorption capacity for dyes from aqueous solution.
In the present work, we developed a novel and efficient method to prepare the core@double-shell structured magnetic halloysite nanotube nano-hybrid absorbent for removal of methylene blue (MB). To achieve this target, HNTs with few functional groups on the outside surface were firstly treated by mussel-inspired method with dopamine to form PDA-functionalized HNTs, as schematically shown in Fig. 1. As PDAfunctionalized HNTs possessed abundant amino and hydroxyl groups
on their surface, which could further attract iron ions (Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions) and co-precipitate into the Fe3O4 nanoparticles on the surface of HNTs by adding reducing agent, thus forming the core/shell structure. Finally, as-obtained core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids were further modified by introducing the KH550 to the PDA system, aiming at achieving a modified mussel-inspired co-modification. In this process, the KH550 was easily hydrolyzed into silanol, which would react with derivatives of PDA via Schiff base reaction and/or Michael addition, thus leading to the polymerization and crosslinking among KH550, PDA and its derivatives on the surface of HNTs/Fe3O4 hybrid. As a result, the well-defined core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids with high surface area and abundant active adsorption sites were prepared, which could promote the high adsorption capacity of MB. Meanwhile, the magnetic core@doubleshell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids absorbent provided the easy separation from water after adsorption of MB by applying an external magnetic field. More importantly, the adsorbed MB can be removed from the absorbent, which allowed the reuse of the adsorbent.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Halloysite nanotubes (Al2Si2O5(OH)4 2H2O, HNTs, diameter: 30–70 nm, length: 1–3 μm) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The crystalline structure of HNTs was shown in Fig. 1. Dopamine hydrochloride (DA) (98%) and tris (hydroxymethyl) aminomethane (≥99%) were purchased from Aladdin, China. Other materials such as ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), ferric chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2·4H2O), ammonium hydroxide (NH3·H2O), methylene blue (C16H18ClN3S 3H2O, MW: 373.9), (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (KH550, 99%) and sodium hydroxide (99%) were of analytical grade and purchased from Kelong Chemical Reagent Factory (Chengdu, China).
2.2. Mussel-inspired modification of halloysite nanotubes by DA
Mussel-inspired modification of HNTs by DA was carried out as follows. 0.5 g HNTs and 0.5 g DA were dispersed in 250 mL of tris (0.394 g) buffer solution at pH = 8.5, followed by stirring at 70 °C for 24 h. The resulting products were separated by centrifugation and washed with deionized water repeatedly, then dried in an oven in 50 °C over night.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids
sections.text: The typical core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids were prepared as follows. 0.1 g of as-prepared PDA-HNTs were dispersed in 200 mL deionized water, followed by adding 0.04 g FeCl2 4H2O and 0.06 g FeCl3 6H2O with vigorous mechanical stirring at 50 °C for 0.5 h. After the temperature was heated to 65 °C, 30 ml NH3 H2O was added to above solution as the reduction agent and maintained for 0.5 h. Then, the synthesized core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids were separated with a permanent hand-held magnet, followed by washing for several times with deionized water and drying in vacuum oven at 50 °C over night. Besides, core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 hybrids with various mass ratios (1:0.5 and 1:3) of PDA-HNTs to iron source were investigated to control the structure and morphology.

sections.heading: 2.4. Construction of core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly
sections.text:
(DA+KH550) nano-hybrids through a modified mussel-inspired comodification
The core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were prepared through a modified mussel-inspired co-
modification. In a typical procedure, a total of 0.5 g of core/shell HNTs/ Fe3O4 nano-hybrids, 0.2 g DA were dispersed in 500 mL of tris (0.8 g) buffer solution at pH = 8.5 by ultra-sonication. Then KH550 (50 mg) was added into the above solution under mechanical stirring at room temperature for 8 h. After rinsing with deionized water and drying in an oven at 50 °C for 10 h, the core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/ poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were obtained.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characterization
sections.text:
The resulting materials were characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR, WQF-520) spectrophotometer between 4000 and 500cm−1 using the KBr pallet technique. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (KRATOS, XSAM800) was carried out to further examine the surface functionalization of HNTs and HNTs/Fe3O4 with using Al Kα as the excitation source (hν= 1486.6 eV). The X-ray diffraction (XRD, PAN analytical Co., Netherlands) patterns were conducted on an X’Pert Pro diffractometer with using Cu Kα radiation source in steps of 2° (2θ) min−1 from 5 to 80° (2θ) at room temperature. The thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) of HNTs, PDA-HNTs, HNTs/Fe3O4 and HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids was carried out by using a SDTA851 (METTLER, Switzerland) thermo-gravimetric analyzer under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from 25 to 800 °C. The micro-structures of HNTs, PDA-HNTs, HNTs/Fe3O4 and HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7500F, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan)
and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI, Tecnai G2 F30, Netherlands). The concentration of MB was measured by the UV–vis–NIR on a UV-762 (Shanghai precision scientific instrument co.).

sections.heading: 2.6. Adsorption experiments of MB
sections.text:
The calibration curve was established by the spectra of standard solution (2.5–20 mg/L).
First, the MB was dissolved into the deionized water to prepare MB solution with the concentration of 1000 mg/L. Different concentrations of MB solutions (70–130 mg/L) were obtained by diluting the above solution.
To investigate the effect of pH on adsorption for MB, the pH of MB solution was adjusted by 1.0 mol/L NaOH and 1.0 mol/L HCl aqueous solution. 10 mg HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were added directly into 100 mL glass conical flasks containing 40 mL MB solution (70 mg/L), which was treated by ultra-sonication for 5 min and shaken at 180 rpm in the water bath at 25 °C for 3 h. The adsorption isotherms of MB were carried out as follows. 10 mg HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were added into the 50 ml MB solution with various concentrations (70, 80, 90, 100, 110, 120 and 130 mg/L) at pH = 10. The adsorption was performed by shaking in the water bath (180 rpm) at different temperatures (298.15 K, 308.15 K and 318.15 K). This process was kept for 3 h to establish the adsorption equilibrium.

sections.heading: 2.7. Desorption and reusability experiments
sections.text: Desorption and regeneration of the adsorbents for MB were studied for five successive cycles. In each cycle, 10 mg of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were added into 50 mL of MB solution with an initial concentration of 110 mg/L at pH = 10, followed by shaking at 180 rpm for 3 h (25 °C). After magnetic separation, the adsorbents were added into 50 mL of ethanol and the pH of solution was adjusted to 3 by using 1.0 mol/L HCl. After shaking for 1 h, the desorbed hybrids were washed with deionized water and used for next cycling. The adsorption capacity of the regenerated HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids was determined by the same method mentioned above.

sections.heading: 3.1. Structure and morphology of core@double-shell structured HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids
sections.text:
To prepare structure and morphology controlled core/shell HNTs/ Fe3O4 nano-hybrids, different mass ratios of PDA-HNTs to iron source were investigated and the results were exhibited by SEM images in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2a and b, raw HNTs had a cylindrical tubular structure and the outer surface was nearly smooth. After coating by Fe3O4 nanoparticles via co-precipitation, it was clearly seen from Fig. 2c–h that the outer surface of the HNTs was changed. When the mass ratio of PDA-HNTs to iron source was 1:0.5 (Fig. 2c and d), few Fe3O4 nanoparticles could be observed on the surface of HNTs, which would affect the adsorption capacity of resulting materials and would not satisfy the purpose of magnetic separation from solution. However, as the mass ratio was increased to 1:1, it was found that proper amount of Fe3O4 nanoparticles were uniformly deposited on the surface of HNTs (Fig. 2e and f), and the structure of HNTs was also well maintained. With the mass ratio further increased to 1:3, a large number of Fe3O4 nanoparticles were loaded on the surface of HNTs, and the cylindrical tubular structure of HNTs was almost invisible (Fig. 2g and h). Besides, it can be seen that serious aggregation of Fe3O4 nanoparticles was observed in Fig. 2g and h, which would cause the opposite effect on the adsorption of MB. Therefore, the core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids with mass ratio of 1:1 were chosen to further construct the core@ double-shell structured HNTs absorbent through a modified mussel inspired co-modification
Fig. 3 showed the FT-IR spectra of raw HNTs (a), core/shell HNTs/
Fe3O4 nano-hybrids (b) and core-double shell HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids (c). In the spectrum (a), the peaks at 3694 cm−1 and 3624 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibrations of Al-OH. The peak at around 1102 cm−1 was assigned to the stretching vibration of Si-O, whereas the adsorption band at 1032 cm−1 was caused by stretching vibration of SieOeSi. The adsorption band observed at 536 cm−1 was attributed to the bending vibration of AleOeSi. The bending vibrations of AleOH at 913 cm−1 and of SieOeSi at 474 cm−1 further confirmed the existence of the corresponding group [28]. These peaks also could be observed in the FT-IR spectra of both HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids and core-double shell HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids. However, a broad peak at 3441 cm−1 was assigned to eOH and eNHe stretching vibration, as shown in Fig. 3b and c. The peak at 1514 cm−1 (as shown in the area marked by the black circle) was assigned to the bending vibration of the eNHe group. These results indicated the successful coating of dopamine on HNTs. More importantly, as shown in Fig. 3c, the peaks at 2927 cm−1 and 2857 cm−1 (as shown in the area marked by the black circle) were attributed to eCH2 nonsymmetrical and symmetric stretch vibration compared with core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids, respectively. These results suggested the existence of KH550. Besides, the peak at 1635 cm−1 was attributed to the C]N stretching vibration, which was a strong evidence for the successful reaction between dopamine and KH550 through Schiff base reaction. The peak of Fe-O at 586 cm−1 could not be observed clearly, which is due to the fact that the peak of AleOeSi of HNTs overlapped with it [17]. From these results of FT-IR spectra, it can be reasonably concluded that the core@ double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids have been successfully prepared.
The successful surface modification of HNTs was further confirmed by XPS spectra. Fig. 4a–c showed the XPS wide scan of raw HNTs (Fig. 4a), core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids (Fig. 4b) and core@ double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids (Fig. 4c), respectively. The characteristic peaks of O1s, Si2s, Al2s, Si2p and Al2p appeared in the spectrum of raw HNTs, and the peak of C1s may come from the impurities. After coating by PDA and Fe3O4 nanoparticles, two new peaks at around 710 eV and 407 eV were detected, which were assigned to the Fe2p and N1s (Fig. 4b), respectively. Furthermore, the intensities of O1s and C1s peaks of HNTs/Fe3O4 were stronger than those of raw HNTs, which confirmed the covalent interaction between HNTs and dopamine. In the final core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids, the peak of C1s enhanced and the O1s decreased obviously because of high content of carbon and low content of oxygen in PDA and KH550. In addition, the peak of Fe2p almost disappeared because the XPS can only penetrate into the sample less than 10 nm [29] while the thickness of poly (DA + KH550) layer was about 50–70 nm from the TEM images (Fig. 7h). It also meant that the detected Si element was just from KH550, which further explained disappearance of Al2s and Al2p. Besides, the C1s spectra of core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/ poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids could be curve-fitted with six peak components at binding energies of 284.6 eV for CeC, at 285.5 eV for CeN, at 286.3 eV for C]N, at 287.2 eV for CeOH, at 288.3 eV for C]O and at 282.3 eV for CeSi. Furthermore, the CeN species could be introduced by dopamine or KH550. The existence of CeSi species confirmed the incorporation of KH550. The C]N species also suggested the chemical reaction between dopamine and KH550, which was consistent with the results of FT-IR. All these results confirmed that the core@ double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were successfully prepared.
The XRD patterns of raw HNTs, core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids and core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were shown in Fig. 5. Compared with raw HNTs, the peaks of (1 0 0), (0 0 1) and (0 0 2) in core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 hybrids and core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids still existed but became weak. Besides,
five characteristic peaks of Fe3O4 at 2θ = 30.12°, 35.45°, 43.03°, 57.01° and 62.60° were ascribed to the (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0), (5 1 1) and (4 4 0) crystal planes, respectively. The results of core/shell HNTs/ Fe3O4 nano-hybrids suggested that Fe3O4 nanoparticles were successfully attached onto the surface of HNTs. Moreover, the peak position of core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nanohybrids was not changed compared with those of core/shell HNTs/ Fe3O4 nano-hybrids, indicating that the crystal structure of Fe3O4 was not changed after coating by poly(DA + KH550) layer.
To estimate the amount of PDA and Fe3O4 attached onto the surface
of HNTs and PDA-HNTs, the thermo-gravimetric analysis was conducted. As depicted in Fig. 6, both raw HNTs and PDA-HNTs exhibited similar degradation behavior. The weight loss of about 14.5 wt% which occurred in the range of 400–550 °C was attributed to the dehydroxylation (Al-OH) of HNTs. However, PDA-HNTs had a larger weight loss (about 9.9 wt%) than raw HNTs in the temperature range of 462–800 °C, which could be related to the decomposition of PDA. Furthermore, after loading of Fe3O4 nanoparticles, the weight loss was increased from 24.3 wt% for PDA-HNTs to 33.8 wt% for core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids, which revealed that the loading amount of
Fe3O4 nanoparticles was 9.5 wt%. Besides, compared with HNTs/ Fe3O4, the increased mass loss (about 8.7 wt%) of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids can be associated with the decomposition of poly(DA + KH550) layer wrapping on the surface of core/shell
HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids. Fig. 7 showed representative TEM images of raw HNTs, PDA-HNTs, core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids and core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids. It can be found that raw HNTs presented a typical cylindrical hollow tubular structure with the open ends (Fig. 7a). In general, the internal and external diameters were 20–30 nm and 30–70 nm, respectively. From the enlarged TEM image (Fig. 7b), the external surface of raw HNTs was nearly smooth. However, the interface of HNTs became obscure after surface modification (Fig. 7c). The comparison of TEM images for single halloysite nanotube (Fig. 7b and d) clearly showed that some irregular polymers were attached onto the surface of HNTs, as shown by the arrows in Fig. 7d. This result further confirmed that the polydopamine layer was coated on the surface of HNTs. Besides, as shown in Fig. 7e and f, Fe3O4 nanoparticles with diameters of 8–10 nm were immobilized uniformly onto the surface of HNTs. By contrast, core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nanohybrids still exhibited a relatively rough external surface (Fig. 7d and f). Therefore, the attachment of Fe3O4 nanoparticles could be related to the adhesion of PDA, which enabled small nanoparticles to adsorb on the surface easily. After modified by dopamine and KH550, it can be clearly observed that poly(DA + KH550) layer wrapped around the surface of core/shell HNTs/Fe3O4 nano-hybrids homogeneously, which confirmed the target micro-structure of core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids. Namely, the doubleshell structured absorbent consisted of a halloysite nanotube as skeleton, an intermediate magnetite nanoparticles coating (as shown by
arrows in Fig. 7h) and poly(DA + KH550) derivate layer outside. Furthermore, as seen from the enlargement of Fig. 7g, the thickness of poly (DA + KH550) layer was estimated to be about 50–70 nm (Fig. 7h)

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of pH on the adsorption of MB
sections.text:
pH has a strong influence on the ionic state of functional groups on the surface of adsorbents. Therefore, the effect of solution pH on removal of MB by core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids was investigated in the range of 3–11. As illustrated in Fig. 8a, the adsorption capacity of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids rose gently as pH changed from 3 to 7. Then, the adsorption capacity increased rapidly as the pH increased from 7 to 10, and further reached the equilibrium as pH varied from 10 to 11. To further explain the reason of change, the zeta potential of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids suspension was determined, as shown in Fig. 8b. The PZC (Point Of Zero Charge) of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids was found to be around 4.5, which meant that the adsorbent surface was protonated to get positive charges with pH below PZC. According to the Eq. (3), the protonation of eNHe was easily happened at low pH to form eNH+ cation. In other words, few eNHe binding sites existed on the surface of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) for MB adsorption at lower pH. Furthermore, since MB was a cationic dye, the electrostatic repulsion between MB and eNH+ was enhanced when more eNH+ were formed on the surface of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550). Hence, the adsorption capacity of MB onto HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids decreased with decrease of pH. By contrast, as the solution pH increased, the adsorbent surface was deprotonated, leading to the increase of eNHe sites on the surface of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550). According to the reaction in Eq. (4), more eNHe groups would form the structure of eNH⋯OH− at higher pH, thus sharply enhancing negative charges on the surface of HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550). Therefore, the electrostatic attraction would facilitate contact and adsorption of MB on the surface of adsorbent. These results further indicated that the pH and electrostatic force played important role in the adsorption process, which affected the interaction between adsorbent and dyes.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of time and adsorption kinetics on the adsorption of MB
sections.text:
Effect of adsorption time on MB adsorption capacity of HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids with different initial concentrations (70 and 90 mg/L) was shown in Fig. 9a. It can be seen that both of two curves exhibited the same trend. The adsorption capacity was enhanced rapidly in the initial stage due to a great number of vacant adsorption sites provided by outer shell poly(DA + KH550) layer. Then, the adsorption capacity slowed down gradually with the increase of time. This was attributed to the gradual occupancy of these adsorption sites, which reduced the efficient interactions between MB molecules and adsorbent. Subsequently, it reached equilibrium within 3 h. It could be attributed to the fact that the remaining adsorption sites were difficult to be occupied because of steric hindrance between MB adsorbed on the surface of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) and solution phase [30]. Besides, the internal particle diffusion of MB molecules into the adsorbent took much time [1].
To investigate the process of adsorption kinetics, the MB adsorption kinetic data were fitted by pseudo-first order and pseudo-second order model. The kinetic equations of these models were described as follows [31]:
− = −ln(q q ) lnq k te t e 1 (5)
= + t q 1 k q t qt 2 e 2 e (6)
where qt (mg/g) is the adsorption capacity of MB at any time. k1 (min−1) and k2 (g mg−1 min−1) are the rate constant of pseudo-first order and pseudo-second order adsorption, respectively. The parameters k1, k2 and qe can be calculated from the slop and intercept of the plots of ln(qe − qt) versus t and t/qt versus t. These results were shown in Fig. 9b, c and summarized in Table 1. The validity of each model was checked by the correlation coefficient R2, as well as the experimental and calculated values of qe.
By contrasting Fig. 9b and c, the fitting degree of pseudo-second order kinetic model was better than that of pseudo-first order kinetic model, which was supported by the correlation coefficient from Table 1. For instance, the correlation coefficient R2 from pseudo-first order kinetic model were only 0.9169 (C0 = 70 mg/L) and 0.8981 (C0 = 90mg/L), which were lower than those of pseudo-second order model (R2 ≥ 0.999). Besides, it was also observed that the
experimental values of qe were in close agreement with the values calculated by using pseudo-second order model, whereas the experimental values of qe differed largely from calculated values obtained by pseudo-first order model. It implied that the pseudo-second order model was more suitable to describe kinetic behaviors of MB onto
HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550). In addition, a chemical adsorption occurred between MB and -NH groups on the surface of absorbent through electron exchange.
The adsorption of any adsorbates onto the solid surface may be a multistep process. In general, the adsorbate first moves from bulk
solution to boundary layer (film) of outer surface of adsorbent, from which it diffuses into the adsorbent surface. Then, the adsorbate diffuses into pores of adsorbent via pore diffusion. Finally, it is adsorbed into the interior sites of pore surface. In order to determine the rate controlling step of the adsorption for MB, the intra-particle diffusion model was applied as follows [30]:
= +q k (t) Ct intra 1/2 (7)
kintra is the intraparticle diffusion rate constant (mg g−1 min−0.5) and C is a constant related with the thickness of boundary layer (mg g−1). If the plot of qt versus t1/2 fits a straight line and passes through the
origin, then the adsorption process is controlled by intra-particle diffusion only; if the data exhibit multi-line plots, then two or more steps have a combined influence on the adsorption process [31].
As illustrated in Fig. 9d, it can be seen that both two concentrations exhibited two stages. The first portion represented the surface or film diffusion and the second exhibited the pore diffusion. The correlation coefficients R2 for intra-particle diffusion model were 0.7779–0.9690 from Table 1, which indicated that the plots were nonlinear. In addition, the plots possessed an intercept which represented the thickness of boundary layer. Therefore, the intra-particle diffusion is not the only step to control the adsorption process. This also confirmed that the
adsorption of MB onto HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) was a multistep process, including adsorption onto the external surface and diffusion into the interior.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of initial concentration, temperature and adsorption isotherm
sections.text:
The equilibrium adsorption isotherms over a range of MB concentration from 70 to 130 mg/L with three different temperatures (from 298.15 to 318.15 K) were carried out to exhibit the adsorption capacity of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids for MB removal. As shown in Fig. 10a, the adsorption capacity increased significantly with increasing initial concentration until reaching equilibrium. This
phenomenon was due to the increase of driving force generated by the concentration gradient. When the initial concentration and temperature were 130 mg/L and 298.15 K, respectively, the adsorption capacity of MB was up to 553 mg/g. In fact, at a fixed adsorbent dosage, the adsorption sites were sufficient for adsorption of MB molecules at lower initial concentration, and the uptake of MB molecules depended on the amount of MB transferring from solution to the surface of adsorbent. However, as the concentration of MB increased in the solution, the surface of adsorbent became saturated so that almost all adsorption sites were occupied. In this case, more MB molecules remain un-adsorbed in the solution, resulting in a platform of adsorption capacity. Besides, it could be clearly observed that the amount of adsorbed MB rose as temperature increased, indicating that the adsorption process was endothermic. This may be due to an increase in thermal energy of adsorbate, which led to higher adsorption capacity. Therefore, the high temperature was beneficial to the adsorption of MB onto HNTs/Fe3O4/ poly(DA + KH550).
To better understand the adsorption mechanism of MB onto the core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nanohybrids, the adsorption data were analyzed with the Langmuir and Freundlich models, which were described as follows [32]:

where qm is the maximum adsorption capacity (mg/g). KL (L/g) is the Langmuir adsorption equilibrium constant. n is am empirical parameter related to adsorption intensity. KF is Freundlich constant representing adsorption capacity. They can be calculated from the slope and intercept of linear plots of Ce/qe versus qe and lnqe versus lnCe, respectively.
The results were shown in Fig. 10b, c and summarized in Table 2. Obviously, as shown in Fig. 10b and c, the Langmuir isotherm exhibited good linearity than Freundlich isotherm. According to Table 2, the correlation coefficients (R2) of Langmuir model for different temperatures were over 0.99, while those of Freundlich model were in the range of 0.933–0.957. These results indicated that the Langmuir isotherm was an appropriate description of data for MB adsorption. These results meant that the adsorption took place at specific homogeneous sites within the adsorbent and the adsorption of MB on absorbent occurred as a single monolayer. Moreover, the maximum adsorption capacity was found to increase from 689.66 to 714.29 mg/g with the increase of temperature from 298.15 to 318.15 K.
The Langmuir isotherm can be expressed in terms of a dimensionless constant RL, which is defined by the following equation [32]:
= + R 1 1 K CL L 0 (10)
where RL indicates that the isotherm is favorable (0 < RL < 1), unfavorable (RL > 1), linear (RL = 1) or irreversible (RL = 0). The RL values in this study were in the range from 0.012 to 0.058 (Table 2), suggesting the favorable adsorption between MB and core@doubleshell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids.
In addition, the values of n calculated by the Freundlich model equation were in the range of 1–10, revealing that the MB adsorption onto absorbent was a favorable adsorption process. The Table 3 presented the comparison of adsorption capacity of as-prepared core@ double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids with those of various adsorbents reported in literatures. Obviously, our core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nanohybrids showed higher adsorption capacity for MB than other used adsorbents, suggesting the potential application for removal of MB in practical wastewater treatment.

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption thermodynamics
sections.text:
The different thermodynamic parameters of an adsorption process could determine its spontaneity, randomness, endothermicity or exothermicity etc. The standard Gibbs free energy change △G°, standard enthalpy change △H° and standard entropy change △S° associated
with the adsorption process were calculated by using the following equations [30]:
°=G - RT ln Kc (11)
= ° + ° R lnK - H RT S c (12)
where R is the gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1). T is the absolute temperature in Kelvin. Kc (qe/Ce) is an equilibrium constant at various temperatures. The values of△H° and △S° could be calculated from the slope and intercept of plot between lnKc versus 1000/T for initial MB concentration of 90 mg/L (Fig. 10d) and the results were listed in Table 4. The negative values of △G° confirmed that the adsorption of MB onto core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids was a spontaneous and feasible process. Moreover, the decrease of △G° (−10.11 ∼ −13.56 KJ/mol) with the increase of temperature indicated that the adsorption was more favorable at higher temperatures. The positive value of △H° (41.42 KJ/mol) revealed that the adsorption reaction was an endothermic reaction, which was supported by the increased adsorption capacity with the increase of temperature. The positive value of △S° (172.82 J mol−1 K−1) suggested that the randomness increased at the solid-solute interface during the adsorption.

sections.heading: 3.6. Regeneration property of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA+KH550)
sections.text:
To evaluate the regeneration property of as-prepared HNTs/Fe3O4/ poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids, five adsorption-desorption cycle experiments were conducted. As shown in Fig. 11a, compared with original removal efficiency of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids (89.6%), the removal efficiency still reached 89% for MB after five consecutive adsorption-desorption cycles, which was attributed to the strong interaction between MB and functional groups of our absorbent. Furthermore, the FT-IR analysis of the sample before and after five adsorption-desorption cycles was shown in Fig. 11b. It can be seen clearly that the peak at 3441 cm−1 corresponding to eOH and eNHe stretching vibration shifted to 3435 cm−1 after five adsorption-desorption cycles, confirming that the interaction of hydroxyl and amino groups with MB molecules still existed. Besides, the characteristic peaks of MB at 1385, 1324 and 883 cm−1 were observed in the spectra of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) after five adsorption-desorption cycles. Therefore, the slight decrease of the adsorption capacity was due to the incomplete release of partial MB adsorbed on HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550) nano-hybrids during desorption process. These results indicated that the HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids can
be repeatedly used as a high-performance adsorbent for the treatment of wastewater.

sections.heading: 3.7. Magnetic separation character
sections.text: The magnetic properties of core@double-shell structured HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids were investigated at room temperature by using a vibrating sample magnetometer with an applied field of −6000 Oe ≤ H≤ 6000 Oe, as shown in Fig. 12a. The magnetic hysteresis curve of the materials illustrated the good magnetic response to a varying magnetic field and its saturated magnetization value was measured to be 10.52 emu/g. The separation behavior of core@doubleshell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids was shown in Fig. 12b. A small amount of core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids was dispersed in 50mg/ L of MB solution. When an external magnet was applied, the nano-hybrids were attracted to the wall of vial and the solution became limpid due to the complete adsorption of MB. Therefore, the recycling process of the adsorbents is more energetically and economically sustainable by using a permanent magnet.

sections.heading: 3.8. The analysis of adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
In order to gain insight into the adsorption mechanism between adsorbent and adsorbate during the adsorption process, the XPS analysis of N1s and O1s before and after adsorption of MB onto HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) were conducted. The peak assignment and group contents of N1s and O1s were summarized in Table 5. As shown in Fig. 13a, the N1s spectrum of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550)
before adsorption could be fitted into three peak components with binding energies of 399.04, 400.34 and 402.8 eV corresponding to the eN], eNHe and eNH2, respectively. After adsorption of MB, the peak position of eNHe decreased to 399.71 eV. Besides, the group content of eNHe was found to be 80.35%, where it was 53.35% before adsorption. These results indicated that eNHe groups as the major adsorption sites were involved in the adsorption process and eNH⋯OH−eMB complexes were formed on the surface of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly (DA + KH550), which was consistent with the assumption of Eq. (4). In addition, it can be seen from Fig. 13b that the O1s spectrum before adsorption displayed two peak components at 532.32 and 532.67 eV for CeOH and C]O, respectively. While the group content of CeOH decreased from 22.43% to 21.51%, and that of C]O increased from 77.57% to 78.49%. The possible explanation could be that the hydroxyl groups on the surface of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) were easier to ionize H+ to form O− under alkaline condition. In this case, the MB

Based on the results mentioned above, the proposed adsorption mechanism of HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) towards MB may be attributed to the fact that HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) possessed a large number of negatively charged amine groups and catechol groups under alkaline condition, which could react with MB through the electrostatic interaction and π-π stacking interaction. Besides, this welldefined core@double-shell configuration and large surface area were favorable to the diffusion of MB molecules, which made the HNTs/ Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) possess high adsorption capacity towards MB.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, novel core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids adsorbent for removal of methylene blue was developed by co-precipitation and modified mussel-inspired comodification route. This well-defined core@double-shell structured absorbent exhibited huge advantages compared with conventional core-shell or hybrid structures. Namely, the core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nano-hybrids showed high adsorption capacity for MB from aqueous solution up to 714.29 mg g−1 at
318.15 K. The high efficiency of the absorbent was attributed to the unique core@double-shell structure, in which the intermediate magnetite nanoparticles coating provided the high surface area and magnetic separation property, and poly(DA + KH550) derivate layer outside afforded the active adsorption sites. It was found that the adsorption followed the pseudo-second-order model. Moreover, the core@double-shell structured HNTs/Fe3O4/poly(DA + KH550) nanohybrids exhibited the well magnetic separation property and recovery ability of adsorption after five cycles of the adsorption/desorption process. The reusability, high adsorption capacity and easy separation from aqueous solution make it be potential for removal of dyestuffs from wastewater.

metadata.abstractText: Design and fabrication of structurally optimized absorbents are important for wastewater treatment such as dyes and heavy metals removal. Herein, we reported the core@double-shell structured magnetic halloysite nanotube nano-hybrid absorbent with target micro-structure and high efficiency removal capacity of dyestuffs. Our core@ double-shell structured absorbent consisted of a halloysite nanotube as skeleton, an intermediate magnetic nanoparticles coating with more specific surface area and magnetic separation property, and poly(DA + KH550) derivate layer outside provided active adsorption sites. This well-defined core@double-shell configuration was quite distinct from conventional core-shell or hybrid structures. The integrated advantages of HNTs skeleton, Fe3O4 nanoparticles inner shell and poly(DA + KH550) outside shell contributed to the high adsorption capacity of methylene blue (up to 714.29 mg g) and excellent cycling stability. Furthermore, the novel core@doubleshell structured absorbent exhibited better removal efficiency for methylene blue in solution with high pH, and the adsorption process can be described by using the pseudo-second-order model. More importantly, the recycling process of adsorbents was more energetically and economically sustainable by using a permanent magnet. The characteristic high removal capacity, cycling stability and easy separation made core@double-shell structured absorbent promising for the efficient removal of dyestuffs from the wastewater.
